text: While genetic engineering might have potential benefits, it's crucial to consider the scientific uncertainties associated with it. The technology is complex and its long-term implications are not completely understood. The unpredictable nature of genetic modifications makes it difficult to fully comprehend and manage their effects. There could be significant risks to ecosystems and human health that we are not yet aware of.

But I would like to use my remaining time on this exchange, Jim, to respond to an exchange that took place just a moment ago. Because a couple of times the governor has said that I am for a bigger government. Governor, Im not. And let me tell you what the record shows. For the last eight years I have had the challenge of running the streamlining program called Reinventing Government. And if there are any federal employees in this group, you know what that means. The federal government has been reduced in size by more than 300, 000 people. And its now the smallest number that we have had since the — the smallest in size since John Kennedys administration. During the last five years, Texass government has gone up in size. Federal government has gone down, Texass government has gone up. Now, my plan for the future, I see a time when we have smaller, smarter government where you dont have to wait in line because you can get services online cheaper, better, faster. We can do that.

While it's true that multiple factors contribute to violence, empirical evidence still supports the effectiveness of gun regulations in reducing gun-related deaths. A study published in the International Journal of Epidemiology analyzed data from multiple countries over several years and found a strong association between stricter gun control laws and lower firearm mortality rates. This comprehensive analysis suggests that while socioeconomic factors are important, implementing stricter gun regulations remains a key factor in reducing gun violence.
